title: Fish stocks and fishing intensity by region

msy.title: Maximum Sustainable Yield
msy.content: The Maximum Sustainable Yield (MSY) is a term used in fisheries science to measure the sustainability of fish stocks. It is the point at which we can catch as much fish as possible without reducing that fish population below the most productive level. It’s where fish catch is equal to the reproduction rate.

subtitle:
Fish stocks are measured by biomass: the number of individuals multiplied by their mass. Fishing intensity by the fraction of the fish population that is caught in a given year.

Both are given as a ratio of their levels at the [maximum sustainable yield](hover::biodiversity::msy) – the level at which we can catch the maximum amount of fish without a decline in fish populations. A value of one maximises fish catch without decreasing fish populations. This is the target level.
originUrl: I was trying to ask if there are only tsvs in owid-content. What makes explorers work is in owid-grapher, right?
sourceDesc: RAM Legacy Database; Hilborn,et al. (2020). Effective fisheries management instrumental in improving fish stock status.

comparisonLines.label: Biomass or fishing intensity at maximum sustainable yield
